Jesus, the more because he had submitted to the fetter of the finite mind, must have felt un- utterable woe when, by the unerring instinct of his divine heart, he per- ceived to the full the shame and, as it were, impregnable falsity of such self- assurance. Believing that the very heart of God was his heart, we realise that he must have felt this, and can follow his words with understanding when we hear him say, with infinite sadness, “If ye had been blind ye should have had no sin: but now ye say, ‘ We see’ ; there- fore your sin remaineth.'’
